facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2441 and 2442 of 1968 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2441 and 2442 of 1968. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 17, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Arbitration Petitions Nos. 49 and 50 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 17, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Arbitration Petitions Nos. 49 and 50 of 1968. N. Shroff, for the appellant

facts.text: The High Court determined under section 33 of the Arbitration Act that the umpire rightly entered upon the reference and extended time till 31 December, 1968 for making an award.

anchor.surface_text: judgment dated 17 October, 1968 of the High Court at Bombay determining under section 33 of the Arbitration Act that the umpire rightly entered upon the reference and further extending the time till 31 December, 1968 for making an award thereof by the umpire.

facts.text: Arbitration agreement between the partnership firm of Indian Engineering Company and Keshavsinh Dwarkadas Kapadia on 26 April, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: On 26 April, 1967 there was an arbitration agreement between the partnership firm of Indian Engineering Company and Keshavsinh Dwarkadas Kapadia.

facts.text: Kapadia appointed Ms. Chetan Trading Company as the sole selling agent by agreement dated 16 September, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Kapadia had appointed M s. Chetan Trading Company as the sole selling agent of Kapadias, several products including aluminium and copper wire by an agreement dated 16 September, 1965.

facts.text: Chetan Trading Company appointed Indian Engineering Company as their sole selling agent in respect of aluminium and copper wires.

anchor.surface_text: Chetan Trading Company in their turn appointed Indian Engineering Company as their sole selling agent in respect of aluminium and copper wires.

facts.text: Chetan Trading Company terminated their agreement with Indian Engineering Company.

anchor.surface_text: Chetan Trading Company terminated their agreement with Indian Engineering Company.

facts.text: Kapadia terminated the sole selling agency with Chetan Trading Company.

anchor.surface_text: Kapadia also terminated the sole selling agency with Chetan Trading Company

facts.text: Indian Engineering Company contended that on termination they became sole selling agent of Kapadia and claimed damages for breach.

anchor.surface_text: Indian Engineering Company contended that on the termination of the sole selling agency between themselves and Chetan Trading Company Indian Engineering Company became the sole selling agent of Kapadia in terms of the agreement dated 16 September, 1965. Indian Engineering Company claimed damages against Kapadia for breach of the agreement.

facts.text: Kapadia claimed damages and moneys from Indian Engineering Company.

anchor.surface_text: Kapadia claimed damages and moneys from Indian Engineering Company.

facts.text: Disputes referred to arbitration per agreement dated 26 April, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose between the parties. These disputes were referred to arbitration in accordance with the agreement dated 26 April, 1967.

facts.text: Similar arbitration agreement between Chetan Trading Company and Indian Engineering Company on 5 June, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: There was a similar arbitration agreement between Chetan Trading Company and Indian Engineering Company on 5 June, 1967 in respect of their disputes and claims against each other.

facts.text: Arbitrators: Shri H. G. Advani and Shri J. N. Gandhi.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 1 All the disputes and differences arising out of or in relation to the said Sole Selling Agency Agreement be and they are hereby referred to the arbitration of the said Shri H. G. Advani and Shri J. N. Gandhi.

facts.text: Arbitrators held first meeting on 12 September, 1967 and appointed umpire Mr. Porus Mehta failing him Mr. Murzban Mistry.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators Messrs. Advani and Gandhi held their first meeting on 12 September, 1967. At the said meeting before entering upon the reference the arbitrators appointed an umpire in the following terms Mr. Porus Mehta failing him Mr. Murzban Mistry appointed umpire.

facts.text: Time for award expired on 11 January, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On 11 January, 1968 the time laid down by clause 5 of the agreement for making the award expired.

facts.text: On 14 January, 1968 respondents wrote to appellants for extension of time.

anchor.surface_text: On 14 January, 1968 the respondents wrote to the appellants to obtain the necessary extension of time for making the award.

facts.text: On 6 March, 1968 appellants wrote to arbitrators alleging bias of Mr. Advani.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondents through their solicitors called upon the arbitrators to refer the matter to the umpire and also by a separate letter called upon the umpire Mr. Porus A. Mehta to enter on the reference as umpire appointed by the arbitrators.

facts.text: Respondents called upon umpire Mr. Porus A. Mehta to enter on the reference.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents through their solicitors called upon the arbitrators to refer the matter to the umpire and also by a separate letter called upon the umpire Mr. Porus A. Mehta to enter on the reference as umpire appointed by the arbitrators.

facts.text: Mr. Mehta fixed meeting on 27 May, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mehta fixed a meeting on 27 May, 1968. The appellants raised certain objections.

facts.text: Meeting held on 17 June, 1968 where Mr. Mehta gave directions and fixed 12 July, 1968 for hearing.

anchor.surface_text: Another meeting was fixed on 17 June, 1968. At the meeting held on 17th June, 1968 Mr. Mehta gave certain directions in regard to the proceedings and instructions thereof and fixed 12 July, 1968 for hearing.

facts.text: Appellants by letter dated 12 July, 1968 contended no consent of umpire obtained.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants by letter dated 12 July, 1968 addressed to Mr. Mehta contended that the consent of the umpire was not obtained before his appointment and therefore there was no valid appointment of the umpire.

facts.text: Appellants filed applications under section 33 of the Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this context of events the appellants filed applications under section 33 of the Arbitration Act which resulted in the order appealed against.

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that no valid appointment of umpire without consent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on the decision of the Judicial Committee in Mirza Sadik Husain v. Mussanmat Kaniz Zohra Begam and Anr. 138 I.A. 181 and held that the umpire signified the consent by taking up the office and the umpire rightly entered on the reference.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals and upheld High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was correct in making the order. The appeals are dismissed. The order of the High Court is upheld,

facts.text: Supreme Court granted umpire Porus A Mehta three months from date of service of order to make award.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the time granted by the High Court till 31 December, 1968 for making the award cannot apply, the umpire Porus A Mehta is granted time for three months to make the award. Three months will run from the date of service of this order by any party to these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee said it appears to their Lordships that when an arbitrator is nominated by parties, his refusal to act is signified as clearly by his refusal to accept nomination as by any other course he could pursue.

arguments.claim: there was disagreement between the arbitrators

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the arbitrators by reason of attitude of a party in correspondence addressed to the arbitrators could not agree to proceed with the matter. Where one of the arbitrators decline to act...

holdings.text: There was a valid appointment of the umpire by the arbitrators without prior consent of the appointee, as consent is not required before appointment and is signified by entering upon the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was correct in holding that there was a valid appointment of the umpire and the umpire rightly entered upon the reference. The umpire's authority commenced when he entered upon the reference on being asked to proceed with the reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment distinct from acceptance; prior consent not required per Mirza Sadik Husain; acceptance by conduct upon call to act.

holdings.text: The umpire rightly entered upon the reference.

anchor.surface_text: determining under section 33 of the Arbitration Act that the umpire rightly entered upon the reference and further extending the time till 31 December, 1968 for making an award thereof by the umpire.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Umpire fixed meetings, gave directions, proceeded with arbitration after time expiry under para 4 First Schedule.

holdings.text: Operation of paragraph 4 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act was not excluded by clause 6 of the arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Arbitration Act provides that an arbitration agreement, unless a different intention is expressed therein, shall be deemed to include the provisions set out in the First Schedule in so far as they are applicable to the reference. Paragraph 4 of the First Schedule provides that if the arbitrators have allowed their time to expire without making an award or have delivered to any party to the arbitration agreement or to the umpire a notice in writing stating that they cannot agree, the umpire shall forthwith enter on the reference in lieu of the arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No different intention expressed in agreement to exclude s3 incorporation of para 4; clause 6 does not limit to explicit difference.

holdings.text: Expiry of time for arbitrators to make award triggers umpire's entry on reference under paragraph 4 First Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 4 of the First Schedule provides that if the arbitrators have allowed their time to expire without making an award or have delivered to any party to the arbitration agreement or to the umpire a notice in writing stating that they cannot agree, the umpire shall forthwith enter on the reference in lieu of the arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of para 4; time expired on 11 Jan 1968 without award or notice of disagreement.

holdings.text: There was disagreement between the arbitrators allowing umpire entry under paragraph 4.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the arbitrators by reason of attitude of a party in correspondence addressed to the arbitrators could not agree to proceed with the matter. Where one of the arbitrators decline to act...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Party's bias allegation and refusal to extend time prevented progress; constitutes disagreement though not explicit difference.

holdings.text: The High Court order under section 33 determining umpire's valid entry and extending time is correct; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was correct in making the order. The appeals are dismissed. The order of the High Court is upheld,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding High Court on both framed issues; para 4 applicable, appointment valid.

holdings.text: Umpire Porus A. Mehta granted three months from service of order to make award.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the time granted by the High Court till 31 December, 1968 for making the award cannot apply, the umpire Porus A Mehta is granted time for three months to make the award. Three months will run from the date of service of this order by any party to these appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court extension lapsed; court exercises s33 power to extend anew.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was correct in holding that there was a valid appointment of the umpire and the umpire rightly entered upon the reference. The umpire's authority commenced when he entered upon the reference on being asked to proceed with the reference.

For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was companyrect in making the order. The appeals are dismissed. The order of the, High Court is upheld, In view of the fact that the time granted by the High Court till 31 December, 1968 for making the award cannot apply, the umpire Porus A Mehta is I-L3Sup.Cl/72 gran

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Arbitration Act provides that an arbitration agreement, unless a different intention is expressed therein, shall be deemed to include the provisions set out in the First Schedule in so far as they are applicable to the reference. Paragraph 4 of the First Schedule provides that if the arbitrators have allowed their time to expire without making an award or have delivered to any party to the arbitration agreement or to the umpire a notice in writing stating that they cannot agree, the umpire shall forthwith enter on the reference in lieu of the arbitrators.

For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was companyrect in making the order. The appeals are dismissed. The order of the, High Court is upheld, In view of the fact that the time granted by the High Court till 31 December, 1968 for making the award cannot apply, the umpire Porus A Mehta is I-L3Sup.Cl/72 gran

For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was companyrect in making the order. The appeals are dismissed.
